a machine readable transcription

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Lightly revised printer's copy of "For Queen Victoria's Birthday," which was published in Good-Bye My Fancy in 1891. In the same folder are an uncorrected proof sheet and an envelope, which is inscribed with a note in Whitman's hand, indicating that he presented them together as a gift to an unknown recipient. No images of the proof sheet are available.

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
The verso is blank except for #22—File "A" which is written in the middle of the page.

lg.note:
An American arbutus bunch, to be put in a little vase on
the royal breakfast table. May24, 1890.
lg.l:
Lady, ‸accept a birth—thought, haply an ideal gift and
token
Right from the ‸scented soil's May⹀;utterance here,
(Smelling of countless, blessings, prayers, and old—time thanks,)

A bunch of white and pink arbutus, ‸silent wildspicy, shy, silent,
spicy,
From Hudson's, Delaware's,or Potomac's woody banks,

note.p:
Note.—
‸ Very little as we ‸Americans stand to this day, with our sixty five or seventy millions of population, an immense surplus in the treasury, and all that,actual power or latentreserved power,‸the land orand sea, so, dear, to nations — Very little ‸I say do we ‸recall and realize ‸that our the ‸curious shuddercrawling when national the "Trent affair" promised to bring upon our shouldersus a war with Great Britain — followed certainly ‸unquestionably! as that war would have been by official recognition of the Southern Confederacy from all the leading ‸European nations. It is now certain that all this ‸quite inevitable to gain of calamity hung on certain arrogant and peremptory phrases, official and prepared, in the ‸prepared and written missive of the British Minister to America which the Queen (and Prince Albert latent) ‸positively and propmptlypromptly canceled; and which by her firm attitude ‸alone did ‸actually erase and leave out aginst all the other powerofficial, prestige and court ‸of St. James's. On such minor and personal issuesincidents (so to call them) turnafter demand the great issues ‸growths and turns of civilization. and history. For oro This goonoble moment of a woman and a queen have surely swung the grandest oscillation of modern history's pendulum. W. W.run on

Many sayings and doings of that period, from p foreign po–
tentatespotentates and powers, maymight had betterwell be dropp'd in oblivion by America — but never this, if I could have my way.
